explain: A repository stores your project files, tracks changes, and maintains version history. It's the home base for your code.
Allows parallel work without conflicts. Create branches to experiment with features without affecting the main codebase.
A snapshot of changes with a descriptive message. Think of it as a save point in your project's history.
Merge code from one branch to another. It's a request to review and integrate your changes into the main project.
Occurs when two edits overlap the same lines of code. Git needs your help to decide which changes to keep.
